Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Center for Advanced Forestry Systems - Phase II
Award.AbstractNarration:
PROGRAM DIRECTOR'S RECOMMENDATION

This proposal seeks funding for a second five-year term (Phase II) of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Advanced Forestry Systems (CAFS) sites including the North Carolina State University (lead), Virginia Tech, Oregon State University and Purdue University. The collaborative research conducted under the CAFS umbrella focuses on optimizing genetic and cultural systems to produce high-quality raw materials for new and existing forest products industries.

Over the past 50 years, much forestry research has taken place in university-based, industry-supported, cooperative research programs. These "coops" continue be extraordinarily successful at achieving research and technological advances on topics of great relevance to the forest industry. However, the ability to focus on specific disciplinary topics in response to industrial guidance is also a limitation. Many of the problems and opportunities facing forestry today, bridge disciplinary and regional boundaries. For technological advances to be made, it is necessary to approach research questions on multiple spatial and temporal scales, including the molecular, cellular, individual-tree, stand, and ecosystem levels. The proposed Center (CAFS) has been successful at providing the administrative structure and funding that has allowed scientists from these existing cooperatives to initiate much need cross-disciplinary research in areas of genetics, site manipulation, and growth and yield modeling. The proposal presents a plan for the 2nd five-year phase for the four original university CAFS sites, North Carolina State, Oregon State, Purdue, and Virginia Tech. This proposal also serves as a research and administrative template for the other five university sites that have joined CAFS since its interception in late 2007.

The research conducted by CAFS increases the competitiveness of forest products industries and forest landowners by solving problems on multiple temporal and spatial scales and determining fundamental solutions that transcend traditional species, regional, and disciplinary boundaries. Member organizations of the Center benefit by becoming knowledgeable about a wider range of technological capabilities. In addition, technology transfer between Center scientists and member personnel fosters rapid implementation of new technologies. The broader scientific community benefits through refereed publications and presentations at scientific meetings. During the Phase II period, graduate student training will continue to be featured in Center research and technology transfer. Aggressive recruiting for graduate students among under-represented groups will be conducted, increasing the diversity of the workforce for both academia and industry in this traditionally diversity-deficient discipline. Opportunities will continue to be sought to involve undergraduate students in Center research activities, exposing them to the excitement of forest science and encouraging them to pursue graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effects of site and genetics on Douglas-fir growth, stem quality, and adaptability

The growth and form of forest tree plantations are affected by the characteristics of the sites on which they are planted.  We studied the effects of site characteristics (climate variables, topographic variables, and soil characteristics) on Douglas-fir productivity, adaptability, and stem form in the Pacific Northwest.  Using the predictive models we developed, foresters now have the ability to estimate the performance of their tree plantations and the potential effects of climate change.  We also developed a web-based tool (Seedlot Selection Tool) that forest managers can use to identify which seedlots are best to plant at a specific site given a chosen climate change scenario.

 

Early genetic selection for wood stiffness in Douglas-fir

High stiffness is an important trait for wood products, and is one of the targets of tree breeding.  However, traditional ways of measuring wood stiffness are expensive and require trees to be cut down.  Newer acoustic tools have been developed that allow wood stiffness to be measured much quicker and without destructive sampling.  We tested these tools and developed recommended approaches for measuring wood stiffness in young Douglas-fir and western hemlock genetic tests.  We studied trees aged 6 to 12 years, which corresponds to the age at which breeding programs would like to incorporate stiffness data into their breeding programs.

 

Development of genetic markers for western white pine and Douglas-fir

Douglas-fir and western white pine are economically and ecologically important forest trees.  We developed genetic markers that will be used to enhance breeding of these species for wood production and disease resistance, and will aid efforts to conserve natural populations.  Genetic markers also have great potential to advance knowledge across multiple fields of study, including functional genomics, ecological genetics, and methods of tree breeding.  Our genetic markers will be made available to the scientific community and private companies for these purposes.

 

Mechanistic growth models: Decomposing phenotypic models into their genetic and environmental components

Growth models have been developed to estimate the growth of Douglas-fir stands and improve their management.  However, forest managers throughout the Pacific Northwest typically use improved seedlots to regenerate new Douglas-fir stands in the region.  To help forest managers use these genetically improved seedlots, we studied how genetic improvement at the individual tree level translates into improved growth at the stand level.

 

Genomic selection for tree improvement

Douglas-fir is the primary focus for many tree breeders in the Pacific Northwest.  Currently, trees undergo many years of expensive field testing before superior genotypes can be confidently selected for future breeding programs.  Thus, tree breeders are highly motivated to find ways to reduce the duration and cost of field testing.  A new approach called genomic selection could revolutionize tree breeding by allowing breeders to dramatically reduce the breeding cycle and extent of progeny testing.  We developed genetic markers (see above) and methods for practicing genomic selection in Douglas-fir.  The approaches we developed can be applied to similar tree breeding programs worldwide.

 

Floral transcriptomics of eucalypts

As a globally important tree crop, there is intense interest in using genetic engineering to add desirable traits to improve growth and resistance to stress.  However, use of genetically engineered (GE) trees is a concern because foreign genes may spread to wild populations.  Thus, we studied ways to impart sterility to eucalypt trees.  This overall goal is supported by three subprojects; (1) floral transcriptomics of eucalypts, (2) FT genes for accelerating flowering in Eucalyptus, and (3) production and analysis of flowering-modified eucalypts.  In this subproject, we identified thousands of genes that are associated with flowering in Eucalyptus grandis.  From this set, we eventually identified four genes that we are using to develop sterile eucalyptus trees via genetic engineering (see below). 

 

FT genes for accelerating flowering in Eucalyptus

Early flowering trees are an important tool for developing sterile eucalypts.  This is because they allow genetic engineering (GE) approaches for imparting sterility to be tested quickly (i.e., at an early age).  We modified eucalyptus trees using GE and a gene from Arabidopsis called FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT).  The resulting trees flowered early, as we predicted.  In addition to using these trees to test sterility (see below), they could be used to accelerate tree breeding.

 

Production and analysis of flowering-modified eucalypts

To produce sterile eucalyptus trees, we used GE to knock-out four floral development genes (TDF1, REC8, EDA33, and LFY).  We used an approach called CRISPR-Cas9, which can be used to selectively target genes to obtain precise genetic changes and desired traits such as sterility.  We obtained sterile trees by targeting the LFY gene, whereas tests of the remaining genes are still underway.  The CRISPR-Cas9 approach might also be used to produce varieties of trees that grow faster, have improved wood quality, or have enhanced resistance to pests or abiotic stresses.
